title: Wills Creek Formation
text:
Wills Creek Formation is a mapped <a href="Silurian">Silurian</a> bedrock unit in <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, <a href="Maryland">Maryland</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>, and <a href="West%20Virginia">West Virginia</a>.
Description.
The Wills Creek is defined as a moderately well bedded greenish-gray shale containing local limestone and sandstone zones, or more specifically as an olive to yellowish-gray, thin-bedded <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a>, <a href="calcareous">calcareous</a> <a href="shale">shale</a>, <a href="Dolomite%20%28rock%29">dolomite</a>, <a href="argillaceous">argillaceous</a> <a href="limestone">limestone</a>, and <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a>. Red shale and siltstone occur in the lower part of the formation. The formation has a thickness between 450 feet and 600 feet in Maryland and 445 to 620 feet in Pennsylvania.
The Wills Creek forms the bedrock of the valley around and to the east of <a href="Lewistown%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lewistown, Pennsylvania</a>.
Fossils.
The Wills Creek Limestone contain fossils from the <a href="Pridoli%20epoch">Pridoli</a> to the <a href="Ludlow%20epoch">Ludlow epoch</a>, or 422.9 to 418.1 <a href="Megaannum">Ma</a>.
Dean et al. (1985) describe the Wills Creek as sparsely fossiliferous.
Conodonts have been identified in the Wills Creek in Virginia ("<a href="Ozarkodina%20snajdri%20crispa">Ozarkodina snajdri crispa</a>" Zone).
Age.
Relative age dating of the Wills Creek places it in the <a href="Silurian">Silurian</a> period. It rests <a href="unconformity">conformably</a> a top the <a href="Bloomsburg%20Formation">Bloomsburg Formation</a> and below the <a href="Tonoloway%20Formation">Tonoloway Formation</a>.
Economic use.
The Wills Creek is a poor source of construction material and is only suitable as common fill.
